questionText: Chechnya is a small Muslim nation.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Chechnya is another name for The Chechen Republic.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: In 1991, the Chechen Republic declared its independence.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: The Soviet Union in broke up in 1991.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Russia maintained that Chechnya did not have the right to secede.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Russia sent troops to the Caucus region in December 1994.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: A war raged between 1994 and 1996.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: In 1996, accords were signed granting Chechnya de facto independence.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: During the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991, Chechnya declared its independence.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: From 1994 to 1996, a war between Chechnya and Russia resulted in the loss of thousands of Russian lives.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: In August and September of 1999, armed Chechen groups invaded neighboring Dagestan, inflicting heavy casualties on Russian troops.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: In mid-2000, Russia claimed they suffered 2,240 killed and 6,372 wounded from conflicts with Chechnya.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: Boris Yeltsin warned more terrorist attacks would be dealt with severely.
author: A2VR9O234UCT9T

questionText: In March 1996, Chechnya won de facto independence.
author: A2VR9O234UCT9T

questionText: Yeltsin expressed support for Chechnya's government.
author: A2VR9O234UCT9T

questionText: By 1999, Russian air raids escalated along the Chechen border.
author: A2VR9O234UCT9T

questionText: A spate of terrorist acts killed over 300 in Russian cities.
author: A2VR9O234UCT9T

questionText: By the end of 1999, Russian troops occupied over 60% of Chechnya.
author: A2VR9O234UCT9T

questionText: During 2000, the Chechen rebels launched isolated attacks.
author: A2VR9O234UCT9T

questionText: In December 1994 Russian troops were sent into Chechnya to crush a separatist drive
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Dzhokhar Dudayev led the separatist drive.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: In March 1996 Boris Yeltsin halted the offensive.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Yeltsin promised free and democratic elections.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Yeltsin suggested amnesty for some combatants.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: At this time Chechnya won de facto independence.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: However, Chechnya was left devastated and lawless.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: In December of 1994 the Russian government made statements indicating an intention to withdraw from Chechnya.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: The withdrawal from Chechnya will be stage by stage.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: The Russian government made statements indicating that Chechnya will remain in the Russian Confederation after the withdrawal.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: Russia launched an anti-terrorist campaign into Chechnya in August of 1998.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: Russia claimed that a provocation for 1998 invasion was hostage taking performed by Chechen rebels.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: In November of 2000 Russians occupied sixty percent of Chechen territory.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: During the Russian invasion 3600 Chechen civilians were killed.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: Post-invasion, Russian forces in Chechnya are still subject to hit and run attacks by rebel forces.
author: A1C7UV2UT2S9T7

questionText: The Russian government has been fighting against Chechen separatists since December 1994.
author: A2YKW761AK4ZGY

questionText: The Russian government announced its intention to withdraw troop from Chechnya
author: A2YKW761AK4ZGY

questionText: Some troops will stay behind and respond to any attacks from the rebels
author: A2YKW761AK4ZGY

questionText: The Russians say Chechnya must stay within the Russian Confederation.
author: A2YKW761AK4ZGY

questionText: The Russians sent in some 30,000 troops to partition Chechnya.
author: A2YKW761AK4ZGY

questionText: By November 2000, the Russians occupied 60% of Chechen territory.
author: A2YKW761AK4ZGY

questionText: Some 3,600 Chechen civilians were killed.
author: A2YKW761AK4ZGY

questionText: Russia occupied Chechnya in 1994-1996.
author: A3L4JI1S352HB8

questionText: Tens of thousands of lives were lost in the 1994-1996 Chechen war
author: A3L4JI1S352HB8

questionText: Russians claimed that air strikes had killed more than 2,000 Chechen rebels.
author: A3L4JI1S352HB8

questionText: The Chechens said air strikes had killed 550 civilians.
author: A3L4JI1S352HB8

questionText: In November 1999 Russia announced its intent to liberate all of Chechnya by February 2000.
author: A3L4JI1S352HB8

questionText: On July 20, 2000 the Russian government announced its troop casualties since Aug. 2, 1999 as 2,518 killed.
author: A3L4JI1S352HB8

questionText: Fighting still continues in Chechnya between Chechen guerrillas and Russian Government
author: A3L4JI1S352HB8

questionText: Chechen rebels have fought against the Russian government.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Terrorist attacks have been launched in major Russian cities as well as in border lands and Chechnya itself.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Russians responded with all-out attempts to occupy Chechnya in 1994-96.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: After August 2, 1999,  Russians secured borders with Chechnya.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: Attempts to subdue Chechen militants through occupation of their homeland have proved costly and ineffective.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: The 1994-96 war cost tens of thousands of lives.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7

questionText: In 1999 Russian forces had occupied only 1/3 of Chechnya.
author: A2Q3FS9G8ITCN7
